Field Operations
The operations of the U. S* Information Service (the field arm of the
U* S. Information Agency) at present include 200 posts in 82 countries.
Each post is an integral part of the diplomatic team, and works under the
general direction of the U. S. Chief of Mission in each country.
The individual post is staffed by a Public Affairs Officer (PAO),
who is in charge, and his assistants. They will include specialists in
news, radio, film, library and other cultural activities. The staff will
vary in number from a single officer at certain posts to many individuals
at the larger posts, end the proportion of Americans to local employees,
as in Europe, is about 1 to 4.
Primarily to strengthen the field programs, the Director of the Agency
has accomplished the following;
(1) Has established a direct line of command over field operations
and direct representation in Washington for the field missions
by appointing Assistant Directors for Europe, the Far East, the
Near East (and South Asia and Africa), and the American
Republics. Spending at least half of their time working in
each respective area, the Assistant Directors will serve as
the eyes and ears of the Director and with authority to act
for him.
(2) Has consolidated the former Office of Policy and Plans and
the Office of Field Programs, at headquarters, into a new
Office of Policy and Programs to improve the development of
information policy and programs which will further U. S.
objectives abroad and promote efficiency.
Media Operations
These are the five media operations of the new Agency which backstop
field activities;
Broadcasting Service
The Voice of America broadcasts more than 75 separate programs
on a world-wide network for approximately 28 program hours daily
in 34 languages. These programs are transmitted via short,

United States and 43 abroad. Included among the transmitters
